title: Short Sellers Find Borrowing Beyond Meat Stock Hasn’t Paid Off
text:
Text size

Shorting stocks is usually the domain of Wall Street’s most sophisticated investors, such as hedge funds. After all, it’s risky. Stocks tend to go up in the long run, making short selling seem like a losing proposition. Higher stock prices aren’t the only vector for short-selling losses though. Stock lending fees can crimp short selling returns—or add to short selling losses.

To sell a stock short investors must borrow actual shares from someone. For every stock sale there is a stock buyer and buyers want actual stock. Lenders of anything, including stocks, want to get paid for lending assets. When a particular short becomes popular, stock lending rates spike because it gets harder for short sellers to find shares to borrow.



It’s basic economics: supply and demand. There are more investors looking for shares to borrow—the demand—than the available supply to lend. When a situation like that arises, stock lenders are in the driver’s seat and can demand high rates for borrowed shares.

Borrowing Beyond Meat (ticker: BYND) shares, for instance, is beyond expensive. In fact, it’s the most expensive stock to borrow in the world, according to data provider S3 Analytics. Short sellers are paying 141% to borrow stock. That’s an annual rate.

Short sellers would be paying far more than 100% of the price of Beyond Meat shares if they stayed short the entire year. That would make it impossible for the short sale to pay off, so clearly bearish investors don’t expect to stay short for long—they must believe Beyond’s stock price will drop soon.

That didn’t happen Thursday though. Beyond shares rose 11.6% after McDonald’s (MCD) said it was testing Beyond’s products at stores in Canada. The test is a big win for the highflying alternative-meat startup.

The high borrowing cost illustrates how controversial the Beyond stock has become. Short sellers balk at the valuation while optimistic growth investors believe alternative-meat is more than a passing fad. The S3 data also shows “smart money” doesn’t like several other highflying startups including Zoom Video Communication (ZM) and Tilray (TLRY). Beyond isn’t the only “hard to borrow” stock.

Investors shorting a basket of nine stocks with borrowing costs greater than 50% would have lost about 21% so far in 2019, according to the S3 report. And that’s not considering stock borrowing costs. Including the cost to borrow shares, the loss would be closer to 60%.

This isn’t just about schadenfreude. There are lessons for investors in the stock lending data. The loss calculation is only theoretical. Most short sellers are keen to cut losses early if things aren’t working. That's an important lesson for aspiring traders. What’s more, the high borrowing costs can tell investors to prepare for volatility.

Beyond meat shares, for instance, have gone from $42 to $234, back down under $140 a share before closing today at $154.34. It’s been a wild ride for investors and for short sellers.

High borrowing cost can also signal higher risk of a short squeeze—the bane of short sellers existence. A short squeeze is a forced repurchase of shares sold short, usually at a much higher price, crystallizing losses for the bears.

Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com
description: Beyond Meat is the most expensive stock to borrow in the world, according to S3 Analytics. Short sellers believe the price will drop soon. But Beyond’s shares rose after McDonald’s said it’s testing the products.
